newsitem.title: GREECE: Merrill Lynch sees limited upside for Greek stocks.
newsitem.headline: Merrill Lynch sees limited upside for Greek stocks.

text.p: Greek equities fall firmly in the sell territory of European emerging markets when weighing forecast P/E levels versus estimated earnings per share (EPS) growth, Merrill Lynch said in a market report.

"We stress that the government will be challenged to sustain the CPI trend without an uptick by year-end. Even if sustained, we see limited potential for further upside when considering the low EPS growth prospects for Greek companies," the report said.
Greek shares have come out of the cold and managed impressive gains of 31.2 percent on the benchmark general share index based on Wednesday's close at 1,252.37.
For the market to sustain and expand upon current valuations, falling inflation and a strong drachma are a prerequisite, Merrill Lynch analyst Mike Harris told Reuters.
January inflation dropped to 6.8 percent year-on-year from 7.3 percent in December 1996, based on the recently revised CPI index.
Although the sense of euphoria could lead to further market gains Merrill Lynch was cautious.
"However, we don't believe the risk-reward profile to be compelling. The market could give up about one third of its gains," Harris said.
The Athens bourse had trimmed mid-session losses of over 2.0 percent on Thursday but was still trading in negative territory, down 1.38 percent.

The market viewpoint was a sobering assessment of Wednesday's bullish outlook by ING Barings which forecast that the bull run of the Greek bourse was sustainable and not speculative in nature. --George Georgiopoulos, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
